introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.text: Welcome to the tutorial page for the WATERWATCH website! WATERWATCH was created for researchers and citizen scientists to report water quality measurements, analyze water temperature trends, and gather data. In this tutorial you will learn how to add your first measurement, navigate the map, and export some water data. This guide is designed for first-time users and experienced researchers looking to get the most out of the WATERWATCH website.

measurement.title: Adding a Measurement
measurement.text1:
This tutorial will be covering how to enter measurement data into the WATERWATCH website. 

For information on how to take a temperature measurement, see 'How to Take Water Temperature Measurements'. 

Using the menu bar, select 'Map'. From the map page you can add a measurement by selecting the + button in the bottom left corner of the screen.
measurement.text2:
This will bring you to a screen where you can enter location, water source, and other relevant information. 

Make sure to double check the values that you record before hitting submit. If you cannot hit the submit button, check that you have filled in all of the required fields with the appropriate values! 

If you would like to reset the form, you can select 'Clear'. Once you have completed the form, select 'Submit'. You will be prompted to confirm your measurement, at which point you can select 'Cancel' to edit your entry, or 'Submit' to save your measurement.

map.title: Navigating the Map
map.text1:
This tutorial will be covering how to navigate the WATERWATCH map. 

Navigate to the map page by selecting 'Map' using the menu bar. You can zoom in or zoom out by selecting the + and - buttons on the top left of the page. To get more information on a certain hexagon, click the hexagon desired. To see data analysis, click the graph icon in the bottom left.
map.text2: To see the map legend, click the button in the top right.

export.title: Exporting Data
export.text1: This tutorial will be covering how to export data.
export.disclaimer: You must be logged in to access export functionality.
export.text2:
Navigate to 'Data' using the menu bar. This will take you to a page where you can select the export type and filters on the data you will be exporting. 

If you would like to export the entire dataset, click 'Search' and select the desired file type in the dropdown. Then click 'Download'.
export.text3: To set filters, select the desired choices from the dropdown or fill in the desired fields and click 'Search' to apply the filters. If you would like to reset the filters, click 'Reset'.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.text: Thank you for taking the time to follow this tutorial on how to use the WATERWATCH website! With the help of researchers and citizen scientists like you, WATERWATCH is able to gather important water data to support scientific research. If you have any questions, feel free to contact the team by navigating to 'Contact' using the menu bar.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.text: Welcome to the tutorial page for the WATERWATCH API! In this tutorial you will learn how to add a measurement and export water data. This guide is designed for first-time users and experienced researchers looking to use the API to add or export measurements.

add.title: Adding a Measurement
add.text:
### Adding a Measurement is done via `POST /api/measurements/`

To create a new `Measurement` (optionally with nested `Temperature` data), send a `POST` with a JSON body to `/api/measurements/`. On success you'll get back just the new `measurement_id`; on failure you'll see `error` details.



Explore the following tabs to get examples for a request, a request using curl, and some sample success and error responses.

error.title: Error Response

export.title: Search & Export Measurements
export.text:
### Search & Export via `POST /api/measurements/search/`

Use this endpoint to filter measurements by date, source, include nested metrics, and choose output format (JSON, CSV, XML, GeoJSON), or get summary stats.

Explore the tabs for how to formulate a request, GeoJSON export, CSV export, default stats response, and error handling.

request.title: Creating a Request
request.text:
#### **Request Body**

Below you will find an example request. Some important notes on formatting your search:
      \- File type to export can be specified by the `format` field. 
      \- Any filters that are left out are implicitly set to include all possible values. 
      \- When filtering by continents and countries, leaving continents empty implicitly returns measurements from any continent. 
      \- If continents are selected but countries are left empty, implicitly all countries in those continents are included in the search. 
      \- Any countries specified must be from the continents that are specified. 
      \- All parameters go in the JSON body.

```http
POST /api/measurements/search/ HTTP/1.1
Host: 
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "location[continents]": ["Europe","Asia"],
  "location[countries]": ["Netherlands","China"],
  "measurements_included": ["waterSources","temperature"],
  "measurements[waterSources]": ["Rooftop Tank","Network"],
  "measurements[temperature][from]": "12",
  "measurements[temperature][to]": "40",
  "dateRange[from]": "2025-05-01",
  "dateRange[to]":   "2025-05-29",
  "times": [{"from":"11:00","to":"16:00"},{"from":"18:00","to":"20:00"}],
  "format":          "geojson"
}
```

default.title: Summary Stats
default.text:
#### **Default Stats Response**

If you omit or set `format` to an unsupported value, you get a count and average temperature:

```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/measurements/search/ \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{}'
```

```json
{
  "count": 256,
  "avgTemp": 18.4
}
```
